dc:title: Egg hatching and resource partitioning in stoneflies: the six British Leuctra spp. ( Plecoptera: Leuctridae).
dc:creator: Elliott J.
dc:description: There were interspecific, but not intraspecific, differences in the percentage of eggs hatching within the temperature range 3.8-19.8oC in the laboratory, optimum temperatures being 6.6-6.7oC (L. geniculata, L. nigra), 8.5-8.7oC (L. hippopus, L. moselyi, L. fusca) and 9.7oC (L. inermis). Over 50% of the eggs of all species hatched in the range 5-15oC. There were interspecific differences in the time taken for 50% of eggs to hatch and length of hatching period in the laboratory; both variables were adequately represented by a negative power-function in relation to water temperature over 3.8-19.8oC. Degree-days could also be used to predict hatching time in L. nigra (363o days) and L. geniculata (369o days). Interspecific differences in egg development in Leuctra spp are related to their habitats and flight periods (months in which adults were present). These variations ensure that eggs of different species are hatching throughout the year so that there is a continual succession of species and hence a reduction in possible competition between closely-related species. -from Author

dc:title: Adult survivorship in Darwin's ground finch ( Geospiza) populations in a variable environment.
dc:creator: Gibbs H.
dc:description: Patterns and causes of adult mortality were studied in Geospiza fortis and G. scandens, on Isla Daphne Major, Galapagos, 1976-1983. The climate ranged from a drought (1977) to exceptionally extensive rains (1983). Annual adult survival in both species varied considerably, and was highest during periods of very light or very heavy rainfall. Mean annual adult survival was 0.69+ or -0.44 for fortis and 0.82+ or -0.21 for scandens. Adult mortality in both species was negatively correlated with the abundance of small seeds per bird. There was also a negative statistical effect of finch density alone on mortality. Survivorship curves of individual cohorts varied considerably in shape, and their age structures were highly unstable. Survival rates of adults of both species were independent of age in most years. An exception occurred during and following an 8-month breedng season in 1983, when fortis aged = or >7yr survived less well than all other birds. Female fortis suffered higher mortality than males in 2 out of 3 dry years. In at least 1yr, differential survival could be attributed to selection against small size. Habitat quality and reproductive activity did not detectably influence survival in either species, but there was a complex interaction between age, sex, habitat quality and survival in both species in some years.-from Authors

dc:title: Stable demographic limit cycles in laboratory populations of Tribolium castaneum.
dc:creator: Desharnais R.
dc:description: Presents a general population matrix model in which the age-specific vital rates depend upon the age structure of the population. The fecundity and survivorship of each age-class are assumed to decrease exponentially at rates which depend on the densities of each age-class. This model is specialized to describe the physiological and behavioural interactions among eggs, larvae, pupae and adults in laboratory populations of Tribolium flour beetles. Laboratory populations can exhibit dynamic behaviours ranging from stable equilibria to demographic limit cycles. -from Authors

dc:title: Lifetime reproductive success of females of the damselfly Coenagrion puella.
dc:creator: Banks M.J.
dc:description: Most variation (70%) in reproductive success arises from variation in survival rather than variation in fecundity. Variation in rate of clutch production accounts for 20% of the variation in reproductive success, and variation in clutch size for only 10%. Females maximize their lifetime egg production by minimizing the interval between clutches, rather than by maximizing the size of each clutch. Since females only engage in reproductive activity on warm, sunny days, weather has a marked effect on female egg production; bad weather means increased inter-clutch intervals and lower egg production. Clutch size is inversely related to body size. However, because large females survive for longer than small females, selection should favour large size in females. Egg size is not correlated with female size. There may be a delayed density-dependent population regulatory process, acting through the reduction in adult female size caused by high larval population density.-from Authors

dc:title: A comparison of methods for estimating the functional response parameters of the random predator equation.
dc:creator: Juliano S.A.
dc:description: Simulations of functional response experiments were used to compare Rogers's linearization, nonlinear least squares, and a new nonparametric parameter space method as means of estimating parameters of the random predator equation. -from Authors

dc:title: Long-term changes in recruitment to the breeding group, and the quality of recruits at a kittiwake Rissa tridactyla colony.
dc:creator: Porter J.
dc:description: The number of recruits to the North Shields kittiwake colony in NE England increased from 1954-1967, but the proportion of first breeders decreased during that time. Increased mortality of the breeding birds or the provision of more sites increased recruitment. This implied that there was a pool of potential recruits from which the new recruits needed could be drawn. In most years there appeared to be a non-breeding reservoir. About 11% of each cohort returned to breed in their natal colony. Immatures did not suffer the same variations in mortality as did adults; this finding is consistent with the premise that increased adult mortality associated with the decline in numbers in the late 1960s occurred prior to the breeding season. Age of first breeding fell from 5 to 4 yr in response to high adult mortality in the early 1970s; body weights and wing-lengths of male and female recruits diminished, but the body weights of male and female prospectors fluctuated little. A model of colony growth is based on the relationship between colony size and rate of increase in expanding colonies of British kittiwakes. Small colonies grow faster than large ones, and are more attractive to recruits. Small colonies cannot produce enough young during the first 70 yr and are sustained by immigration. The North Shields colony is not a closed system and is not currently growing; it is supported by immigration. There is a positive relationship between colony size and nesting density; colony growth appeared to be limited by the number of attractive sites in the dense centre of the colony. -from Authors

dc:title: Systems analysis of acarine predator-prey interactions. I. A stochastic simulation model of spatial processes.
dc:creator: Nachman G.
dc:description: The model describes interactions between prey and predators within a large number of spatially separated patches (plants) as well as dispersal of individuals between these patches. The model includes behavioural responses of mites to intra-patch stimul such as the prey's response to resource depletion and the predator's functional and aggregative response. Using Tetranychus urticae/Phytoseiulus persimilis as a reference system, the model accounts very well for the typical 'hide and seek' strategy. Local extinctions of prey and predators occur frequently but the system may persist owing to an overall balance between local extinctions and colonizations.-from Author

dc:title: Population dynamics and life history of two contrasting populations of Ligia oceanica ( Crustacea: Oniscidea) in the rocky supralittoral.
dc:creator: Willows R.I.
dc:description: Individuals were essentially semelparous. Minimum age at 1st reproduction was one year, but there were 2 distinct breeding groups each summer. Longevity was higher and fecundity and reproductive allocation lower at the less exposed site, but differences were small and the populations were otherwise remarkably similar. -from Author

dc:title: Competition between larvae of the field cricket, Gryllus bimaculatus ( Orthoptera: Gryllidae) and its effects on some life- history components of fitness.
dc:creator: Simmons L.
dc:description: Larval competition tended towards the contest end of the contest-scramble spectrum. Larvae showed well defined aggressive behaviours and those successful in competition monopolized access to food resources, resulting in a few individuals obtaining large adult weight at the expense of others. Females were more successful in competition, resulting in a sexual dimorphism in size when competition was intense. Mortality rates indicated a contest-type outcome of competition resulting in stable population dynamics. Adaptive developmental responses to increased stress should preserve the life-history components most important to fitness at the expense of less critical ones. Stress induced by increases in larval competition caused reductions in realized adult body size and decreased survival while development speed was maintained, suggesting a greater relative importance of development speed to net fitness.-from Author

dc:title: Reproductive strategy of the freshwater pearl mussel Margaritifera margaritifera.
dc:creator: Bauer G.
dc:description: A 1st component of the reproductive strategy is a combination of a 'high life expectancy during the reproductive period', a 'high fertility which is independent of age' and an 'absence of a postreproductive period' resulting in a single female producing approx 200 X 106 glochidia during its reproductive life span of up to 75yr. A 2nd component reflects the selective values of different modes of reproduction at varying population densities. At high densities most animals are dioecious. At low densities females become hermaphrodites and self-fertilization dominantes. But also under these conditions the males probably compensate for some of the deleterious effect of inbreeding. Due to the extended reproductive period populations are less vulnerable to fluctuations in reproductive success; the reprodutive costs are evenly dispersed over the reproductive period, even sparse (founder) populations can persist for a long time and can reproduce successfully. -from Authors

dc:title: Population regulation in contrasting populations of trout Salmo trutta in two Lake District streams.
dc:creator: Elliott J.
dc:description: Compared the population dynamics of Salmo trutta, in Wilfin Beck, populated only by resident brown trout, and in Black Brows Beck which serves as a nursery for the progeny of migratory trout (a mxiture of sea and estuarine trout). Survivor density and loss-rates at different stages in the life cycle were strongly 'density-dependent' on egg density in Black Brows Beck, but simple proportionate survival occurred in Wilfin Beck and loss-rates were more constant than those in Black Brows Beck. Population density in Black Brows Beck was regulated by density-dependent survival in the early stages of the life cycle. There was no evidence for similar density-dependent regulation of the trout population in Wilfin Beck. Summer droughts reduced survival in both populations, the effects being more marked for trout in their 2nd year. Spates also affected trout survival in Wilfin Beck. -from Author

dc:title: Seasonal and spatial variation in juvenile survival of the cabbage butterfly Pieris rapae: evidence for patchy density- dependence.
dc:creator: Jones R.E.
dc:description: The population densities of late-stage larvae of Pieris rapae in the Canberra area appear to be determined primarily by the action of natural enemies. Spatial and temporal variation in 5th instar larval numbers were influenced mainly by variation in larval survival rates, rather than by variation in the numbers of eggs being laid. Juvenile survival was high in spring and autumn but low in summer, due to increased activity by predatory ants in the summer. Natural enemies were also responsible for high spatial variability in survival, there were large differences in the impact of predators, virus disease, and braconid parasites. When survival rates of whole cohorts were compared, there was little evidence of density-dependent effects, but within patches where average mortality rates were high, survival was better on those plants in the patch carrying fewer larvae. Density-dependent mortality (due mainly to predation) was thus spatially and temporally patchy, making it invisible to normal life-table analysis of whole cohorts. Ovipositing females are not concentrated in patches low in natural enemy activity. Because females are highly mobile, this means that patchy density dependence in juvenile survival may be able to regulate densities in the whole breeding population below the limit set by the larval food supply.-from Authors

dc:title: Adaptive patterns in the avoidance of superparasitism by solitary parasitic wasps.
dc:creator: Hubbard S.
dc:description: Parasitic Nemeritis canescens discriminated between hosts (larvae of the flour moth Plodia interpunctella) containing their own progeny and those containing the progeny of other individuals when deciding whether or not to avoid superparasitism. This differential discrimination lasted for c48 hr. The ability of a parasitoid to detect prior parasitism, and avoid subsequent superparasitism, seemed to depend on the operation of a specific chemical marker, originating in Dulfour's gland, and introduced into the host with each egg laid. -from Authors

dc:title: The allometry of food intake in grazing ruminants.
dc:creator: Illius A.W.
dc:description: Due to the allometric relations of bite size and metabolic requirements to body size, small animals can subsist on shorter swards than larger animals. The density of nutrients in the grazed horizon of the modelled swards markedly affected the ability of animals of a given body size to satisfy their energy requirements. The allometric relationships would be expected to apply in selective grazing and browsing species in their choice of food items of different size and nutrient content. Simulation results support the argument that sexual segregation and habitat choice of dimorphic species is an effect of scramble competition for limited resources, the males thus being excluded from mutually preferred swards. The model provides an explanation for 2 interspecific phenomena amongst grazers: grazing succession and grazing facilitation.-from Authors

dc:title: The ecology of small mammals in urban habitats. I. Populations in a patchy environment.
dc:creator: Dickman C.
dc:description: Habitats in the city of Oxford were classified as woodland, scrub, orchard, long grass, short grass, allotment, detached, and semi-detached house garden. Apodemus sylvaticus occurred in all habitats and in 84% of patches, and reached maximum densities (c. 70-80 ha-1) in scrub. Clethrionomys glareolus occurred in all habitats except allotment, and achieved maximum abundance (<30 ha-1) in woodland. Microtus agrestis and Sorex araneus were largely absent from cultivated gardens, allotments and short grass, and were most abundant (50-66 ha-1) in long grass and scrub. Densities of all species were strongly influenced by the density of vegetation at particular heights above ground, and more weakly by indexes of habitat modification and urban disturbance. Small mammals do not perceive the urban environment directly, but respond to it indirectly if it modifies the growth or structure of patch vegetation. -from Authors

dc:title: An improved method for survival rate analysis from time series of haematophagous Dipteran populations.
dc:creator: Holmes P.
dc:description: A method of estimnating the oviposition cycle duration and survival rate of haematophagous Diptera from time-series data has been improved by incorporation of weighted linear regressions and filtered cross-correlations. Time series for Culex quinquefasciatus (Culicidae), Culicoides obsoletus, C. imicola and C. newsteadi (Ceratopogonidae), and Simulium damnosum s.l. (Simuliidae) were reanalysed. -from Authors

dc:title: Feeding behaviour and foraging strategies of captive phyllostomid fruit bats: an experimental study.
dc:creator: Bonaccorso F.
dc:description: Feeding rhythms, rates, and fruit selectivity were observed in flight cage experiments involving 7 species of frugivorous bats from 2 foraging guilds: canopy frugivores specializing on superabundant fruits of canopy trees, and groundstorey frugivores specializing on fruits of shrubs and understorey trees of low fecundity. Canopy frugivores fed continuously throughout most of the night and ate each fruit slowly. Groundstorey frugivores fed in a series of discontinuous bouts separated by periods of roosting/sleeping and ate individual fruits rapidly. Groundstorey frugivores selected fruits high in nutrient content. Canopy frugivores selected familiar fruits of low nutrient content over nutritionally higher quality fruits that wild conspecifics rarely eat. Exploitation competition for some limited food resources may have led to resource partitioning and foraging specialization in neotropical bat communities.-from Authors

dc:title: Recent changes in host usage by cuckoos Cuculus canorus in Britain.
dc:creator: Brooke M.
dc:description: Over the past 40yr there have been significant decreases in the percentage of dunnock Prunella modularis, robin Erithacus rubecula and pied wagtail Motacilla alba nests parasitized by cuckoos as well as a significant decrease in the use of minor hosts, but the percentage of reed warbler Acrocephalus scirpaceus nests parasitized has more than doubled. Cuckoo reproductive success is significantly higher with reed warbles than with other hosts. This is not, however, the complete explanation of the recent increase in parasitization rate of reed warblers. The accuracy of the cockoo's mimicry of reed warbler eggs has not changed over the past 50yr. Cuckoo numbers have declined from approx 34 500 females breeding each year in the period 1939-61 to 21 000 in 1972-82. The rapid changes in parasitization rates in relation to changes in cuckoo numbers are discussed, as is the evolutionary arms race between cuckoos and their hosts.-from Authors

dc:title: The foraging strategy of Diaeretiella rapae. I. The concept of the elementary unit of foraging.
dc:creator: Ayal Y.
dc:description: The searching behaviour of Diaeretiella rapae, the main parasitoid of the cabbage aphid Brevicoryne brassicae, was analysed using whole Brussels sprouts plants. Diaeretiella directed its search on the plant: areas where aphids, or cues indicating their presence, were most expected were preferentially searched, and honeydew secreted by the aphids was used by the wasp as a kairomone for host location. The spatial configuration of the plant and the distribution of aphids and their cues on it have served as a template on which the Diaeretiella foraging strategy has been moulded by natural selection. The individual plant is thus an 'elementary unit of foraging' within the wasp environment.-from Author

dc:title: Age-related effects in oystercatchers, Haematopus ostralegus, feeding on mussels, Mytilus edulis. I. Foraging efficiency and interference.
dc:creator: Goss-Custard J.
dc:description: The intercept of the curve relating intake rate to oystercatcher density (the 'interference curve') was used as an estimate of foraging efficiency, ie the intake rate in the absence of competition. The slope of the curve was used as an estimate of susceptibility to interference, ie by how much a unit increase in bird density affected intake rate. Intake rate was measured over a range of bird densities up to a limit of 1000 birds ha-1. In adults, the intercept of the interference curve decreased gradually from August to the following spring and summer, presumably as the food supply deteriorated. The foraging efficiency of juveniles was only 44% that of adults in August, but was similar by February. This suggests that the foraging skill of juveniles that fed consistently on mussels through the winter improved rapidly. Foraging efficiency in juveniles decreased temporarily again in April when inexperienced birds, which had probably fed on other prey during the winter, returned to the bed. Adults ate larger mussels than did juveniles in autumn, but thereafter there was little difference. Birds in all age-groups changed from eating large mussels at a slow rate in winter to eating small ones at a fast rate in spring and summer. None of the age-classes suffered interference in August. Interference increased as the winter approached, particularly in the juveniles. By February, the juveniles were almost twice as badly affected as the adults by the interference. Neither the juveniles or the adults experienced interference in spring and summer when they ate small mussels. -from Authors

dc:title: Temporal variation in colony populations of the ant Myrmica sulcinodis. II. Sexual production and sex ratios.
dc:creator: Elmes G.
dc:description: On average, 40% of colonies were small and reared no sexuals. In the remainder, sexual production was very variable, having a small significant correlation with worker number (+ve) and queen number (-ve). Sexual production differed significantly from year to year, but not between sites. Colonies form 4 groups, according to whether they rear gynes, males, both or neither. Both study populations had a male bias, greatest in highly polygynous colonies and least in large colonies, as is expected under kinship theory. The social regulation of sexual production at the colony level may be difficult to modify by natural selection, which operates instead on the colony structure required to maximize the species' breeding success in its chosen habitat. If secondary polygyny is an adaptation that ensures a colony's survival in a variable habitat, then many colonies exist for long periods in sub-optimal nest sites. Male bias is the global cost of the polygynous lifestyle for these species. In such populations only the largest and reproductively most successful colonies might approach the optimal sex ratio; these colonies averaged a 1:1 sex ratio (3:1 females by dry weight). -from Author

dc:title: Predicting windborne displacements of the brown planthopper, Nilaparvata lugens from synoptic weather data. 1. Long distance displacements in the north-east monsoon.
dc:creator: Rosenberg L.
dc:description: Nilaparvata lugens makes windborne movements from the tropics to N China, Korea and Japan each spring and return to S China in autumn. Some of these movements are >750 km.-from Authors

dc:title: Microhabitat and seasonal niche dynamics of smooth and palmate newts, Triturus vulgaris and T. helveticus, at a pond in mid- Wales.
dc:creator: Griffiths R.
dc:description: Triturus vulgaris and T. helveticus were present in the pond from February-July, with highest numbers in April. Both species preferred the open water area of the pond to the swamp, and in deep water were mainly bottom dwellers. Microhabitat niche metrics displayed seasonal trends with lowest overlap in March. Seasonal niche breadths and overlaps were generally narrower around the shorelines than in deep water areas. There was no evidence of resource partitioning between the species. Such a situation may arise if the available niche space is unsaturated by adult newts, with population regulation occurring during another phase of the life cycle. -from Author

dc:title: The dynamics of the viburnum whitefly ( Aleurotrachelus jelinekii): a case study of population regulation.
dc:creator: Hassell M.
dc:description: A model is developed of the whitefly population per bush in which the total eggs are distributed from leaf to leaf according to a negative binomial distribution and survivorship per leaf is density-dependent. The failure to detect the important density dependence acting upon this population using key factor analysis arises primarily because of the spatial scale upon which the density dependence operates, in conjunction with the stochastic elements that are present.-from Authors

dc:title: Group living in the European rabbit ( Oryctolagus cuniculus): mutual benefit or resource localization?
dc:creator: Cowan D.P.
dc:description: The social structure and demography of a free-living rabbit population, living on a 10ha bowl of chalk downland in Oxfordshire, England, were studied for 6yr. The population was divided into 11-14 breeding groups, each containing 1-8 males and 1-12 females. Some 89% of males and 96% of females lived in groups containing at least one other rabbit of the same sex. Nest sites were both localized and limited in their availability, which imposed a group-living habit on many females. These female groups attracted males up to an average group sex ratio of 1.5 females per male. Females living in groups containing >1 female had lower 'lifetime reproductive success' than those that lived with males only. Hence, the costs of group living apparently outweighed the potential benefits. Also male survivorship did not increase with group size. -from Author

dc:title: Territory size and population limits in mangrove termites.
dc:creator: Adams E.
dc:description: In Nasutitermes nigriceps and N. corniger, studied in mangrove forests on the Atlantic coast of Panama, foraging areas were defended intra- and interspecifically. Habitat structure strongly affected territory size. Where prop roots of the red mangrove Rhizophora mangle provided connections between trees, territories could grow to enormous sizes (range 1-1750m2), and many colonies bordered neighbours along the perimeters of their foraging areas. Large battles occasionally broke out at points of contact. Where R. mangle was absent, lack of connections between trees limited territory area to 1-2 trees (range 1-110m2); many apparently suitable areas remained unoccupied. In forests with R. mangle, territory size and nest volume were highly correlated. The relationship was nearly linear, suggesting that the biomass of termites supported per unit area of forest was independent of territory size. An increase of one litre in nest volume was associated with an increase of 3.77m2 in foraging area. In populations of social insects, territorial aggression mediates the growth of colonies at the expense of neighbours. The limit to population growth imposed is not a maximum density of colonies, but is instead a combined function of colony biomass and density.-from Authors

dc:title: Random patch formation and weak competition: coexistence in an epiphytic chironomid community.
dc:creator: Tokeshi M.
dc:description: Random patch formation; whereby species form patches of aggregation independently of each other, has in effect contributed to spatial segregation of species in this community in a small river in E England. No significant differences were observed between species in their capacity to colonize new habitats. Time to reach 95% of the naturally occurring density was mostly in the range of 5.6-13.2 days. Random patch formation as well as the absence of strong interspecific competition facilitate the coexistence of species in this community.-from Authors

dc:title: Temporal variation in colony populations of the ant Myrmica sulcinodis. I. Changes in queen number, worker number and spring production.
dc:creator: Elmes G.
dc:description: At 2 heathland sites in S England, the number of workers was on average 120 per colony, but varied with time and between sites; this is interpreted in terms of a regenerating heathland habitat. The number of new workers, reared in spring, varied annually; much of the variation is explained by the size of the colonies and most of the remainder by the effects of weather during the larval growth period. Spring humidity is a good descriptor of new worker production, although humidity itself is a combined expression of several other climatic variables. Number of queens in the colony had no effect on the number of new workers that were reared. New queens are reared by <25% of the colonies. Number of queens varied annually; once the effect due to variation in the size of colonies was removed, the number followed a cycle best described by a sine-wave. The wave has a periodicity of 4-5 yrs and an amplitude of c 3 queens in a colony of average size. The periodicity may represent the average longevity of the queens. -from Author

dc:title: Detecting regulation in patchily distributed animal populations.
dc:creator: Hassell M.
dc:description: A model for an insect herbivore in a patchy environment is used to illustrate difficulties in detecting density-dependent regulatory processes from temporal series of life-table data that ignore within-generation heterogeneity. In a deterministic world there is no problem: spatial and other patterns of density dependence acting on populations within generations translate directly to density dependence acting on total population between generations. Introduction of stochastic variation can change this clear-cut picture, although random variations in net reproductive rate have little effect. In particular, variability in the parameters governing spatial distribution and within-patch survival can lead to spatial density dependence being overlooked using the conventional technique of plotting mortality against population size from generation to generation. This outcome is made more likely if relatively few generations are available and only a small subset of the total patches are sampled. -from Author

dc:title: Survival in five southern albatrosses and its relationship with their life history.
dc:creator: Weimerskirch H.
dc:description: Mean survival rate is 0.912 for yellow-nosed albatross Diomedea chlororhynchos, 0.881 for black-browed albatross D. melanophris, 0.973 for light-mantled sooty albatross Phoebetria palpebrata and 0.950 for sooty albatross P. fusca. For wandering albatross D. exulans, survival rates were the same in 2 colonies and varied identically. During a period of decrease of the population, mean survival rate was 0.909 and reached 0.968 during the following stable period. In addition to the survival rates, other life-table parameters for the 5 species are provided and used to calculate growth rates of the different populations. Differences in the demographic strategies of the 5 species are related to differences in their feeding behaviour in exploiting the available marine resources.-from Authors

dc:title: Changes in the size of groups and ranges of the European badger, ( Meles meles L.) in an area in Scotland.
dc:creator: Kruuk H.H.
dc:description: Badger density was 2.2 km-2, with no significant change over 5 yr. There was a decrease in biomass of the most important food, Lumbricus terrestris, but its distribution remained the same. The size of clan territories fluctuated, but did not change significantly. There was an increase in overlap between neighbouring ranges. Every year 26% of males joined a neighbouring clan, but no female was known to do so. When food availability is relatively low, the badger's spatial organization may revert from strictly territorial clans to the more general mustelid pattern of solitary single-sex ranges.-from Authors

dc:title: Feeding rates of seals and whales.
dc:creator: Innes S.
dc:description: Rates of food consumption by marine and terrestrial mammals are not significantly different when comparisons are made under appropriately standardized conditions. -from Authors

dc:title: Interactions between a generalist herbivore, the moose Alces alces, and its food resources: an experimental study of winter foraging behaviour in relation to browse availability.
dc:creator: Vivas H.
dc:description: At high densities of birch saplings, moose ate less on each sapling, selected twigs of better quality and browsed on more saplings per plot. High-density plots were not visited more frequently than low-density plots. Instead the moose moved longer distances in the high-density plots and probably spent more time there. The proportion of the available browse exploited decreased curvilinearly as food availability increased. Thus, exploitation of browse was strongly determined by its spatial distribution. Factors that influence the spatial organization of plants may also affect both their potential as food supply for herbivores and the type of anti-herbivores strategy which the plant is likely to evolve. -from Authors

dc:title: Relationship of deer and moose populations to previous winters' snow.
dc:creator: Mech L.
dc:description: Linear regression was used to relate snow accumulation during single and consecutive winters with white-tailed deer Odocoileus virginianus fawn:doe ratios, moose Alces alces twinning rates and calf:cow ratios, and annual changes in deer and moose populations. Significant relationships were found between snow accumulation during individual winters and these dependent variables during the following year, but strongest relationships were between the dependent variables and the sums of the snow accumulations over the previous three winters. The percentage of the variability explained was 36-51%. Significant relationships were also found between winter vulnerability of moose calves and the sum of the snow accumulations in the current, and up to 7 previous, winters, with 49% of the variability explained. These relationships imply that winter influences on maternal nutrition can accumulate for several years and that this cumulative effect strongly determines fecundity and/or calf and fawn survivability. Although wolf Canis lupus predation is the main direct mortality agent on fawns and calves, wolf density itself appears to be secondary to winter weather in influencing the deer and moose populations. -from Authors

dc:title: Short-term coexistence and long-term competitive displacement of two dominant species of Iridomyrmex: the successional response of ants to regenerating habitats.
dc:creator: Haering R.
dc:description: Provides strong evidence of spatial competition between 2 species of Iridomyrmex. Experimental removal of one species from an area resulted in a substantial expansion into the area by the other species. These species actively defend space by patrolling territorial boundaries which are highly dynamic and readily breached when patrols are eliminated. Interspecific colony boundaries are separated by a narrow zone of vacant space that has the effect of reducing large-scale confrontations to a few individual skirmishes. These species coexist terrestrially by establishment and maintenance of mutually exclusive spatial distributions mediated by competition. The mechanism of competition is interference, or more exactly, territorial competition. Competitive displacement facilitates successional replacement of these two ant species in response to the gradual shift in habitat parameters as vegetation regenerates after mining. -from Authors

dc:title: The clonal ecology of Daphnia magna ( Crustacea: Cladocera). I. Temporal changes in the clonal structure of a natural population.
dc:creator: Carvalho G.
dc:description: Extensive, and sometimes rapid, changes occurred in the number of clones present and in clone size. Changes in clonal structure were remarkably uniform throughout the lake suggesting frequency changes in response to temporal environmental changes. The study demonstrates rapid genetic changes, and suggests that ecological generalists, opportunists, and seasonal specialists may coexist within a single, primarily parthenogenetic Daphnia population.-from Authors

dc:title: Movers and stayers: foraging tactics of young-of-the-year brook charr, Salvelinus fontinalis.
dc:creator: Grant J.
dc:description: Young-of-the-year (YOY) brook charr use 2 foraging tactics in streams: movers swim slowly while foraging, stayers remain stationary and swim only to intercept food items. The general hypothesis was tested that sit-and-wait foragers (stayers) specialize on fast-moving prey (drift) whereas active foragers (movers) feed more on relatively sedentary prey (benthos). A simple encounter rate model made the following specific predictions: 1) movers have a higher foraging rate than stayers in zero current; 2) the foraging rate on drifting invertebrates by stayers increases with current velocity in the foraging zone; 3) movers have a higher benthic foraging rate than stayers in running water; and 4) there is no difference in the foraging rate on drifting invertebrates of movers and stayers in running water. Results were generally consistent with the predictions but, in zero current, movers apparently shifted their foraging effort to the surface of the water and away from the benthos. Benthic prey were apparently less accessible in silt substrates than in sand or gravel. Also, the drift foraging rate of stayers (20-29 mm in length) decreased at current velocities >7.5 cm s-1. In running water, movers directed more of their foraging atempts toward the benthos than did stayers.-from Authors

dc:title: Early development and population dynamics in red deer. II. Density-independent effects and cohort variation.
dc:creator: Albon S.
dc:description: Early growth and development have a permanent effect on reproductive success of Cervus elaphus on Rhum, presumably because the prevailing environmental conditions in the 1st summer of life influence adult size.-from Authors

dc:title: Early development and population dynamics in red deer. I. Density- dependent effects on juvenile survival.
dc:creator: Clutton-Brock T.
dc:description: For Cervus elaphus on Rhum, survival of calves through their 1st year of life was related to birth weight and birth date. As population density increased, average date of parturition became later. Mean birth weight did not change, but at high density, its influence on over-winter calf survival intensified. These 2 effects were resonsible for much of the increase in over-winter calf mortality at high population density.-from Authors

dc:title: Sycamore aphid numbers and population density. III. The role of aphid induced changes in plant quality.
dc:creator: Wellings P.
dc:description: Leaf age of Acer pseudoplatanus had a marked effect on the performance of Drepanosiphum, platanoidis. Aphids reared on young leaves grew at significantly greater rates, had shorter development times and achieved greater adult weights than those reared on older leaves. Leaf infestation history had no significant effect on aphid performance. Aphid infestation at bud-burst had a marked effect on the host-plant, reducing the area of the leaves to <50% the area of leaves on uninfested trees. -from Authors

dc:title: Age-related effects in oystercatchers, Haematopus ostralegus, feeding on mussels, Mytilus edulis. II. Aggression.
dc:creator: Goss-Custard J.
dc:description: When juvenile oystercatchers first arrived on the Exe, they were very aggressive and attacked other birds more often than did the adults. However, their aggressiveness declined through the winter, both in absolute terms and relative to that of the adults. Young birds then remained less aggressive than adults for several years, when they became adult themselves. When they first arrived, juveniles were only slightly less successful in aggressive encounters than adults. Their success declined during the winter. Compared with adults, more of the attacks made by juveniles throughout autumn and winter were attempts to steal mussels found by other birds. Compared with adults, juveniles in autumn had a high proportion of the mussels they found for themselves stolen from them, but they also stole from other birds a high proportion of the ones they ate themselves. Both proportions declined during the winter, and were similar to the less variable adult values by February. Stealing was uncommon in all age-groups in spring and summer when small mussels were being eaten. -from Authors

dc:title: Population regulation in deer mice: the role of females.
dc:creator: Galindo C.
dc:description: The influence of adult females on juvenile survival was demonstrated in a population of Peromyscus maniculatus during the snow-free season of 1983 in the S Yukon.-from Authors

dc:title: Handling effects in Heliconius: where do all the butterflies go?
dc:creator: Mallet J.
dc:description: Individuals were less likely to return to flowers after being captured and handled than after being identified by sight alone. This handling effect lasted up to 2 days after capture. Fidelity to particular nocturnal roost sites, however, was not affected by initial capture and marking or recapture during the day, apart from a short-term effect on the night of the day that captures were made. Heliconius avoid specific sites where they have been handled, but do not completely desert their home ranges. Because of these handling effects, mark-recapture estimates of population size are likely to be inaccurate. -from Authors

dc:title: Ants, parasitoids, and the cabbage butterfly Pieris rapae.
dc:creator: Jones R.
dc:description: Ant predation by 2 species of Iridomyrmex had a major impact on juvenile survival of Pieris rapae populations in the Canberra area. Ant predation fell most heavily on the later instars; in the absence of ant predation, survival of instars III-V was very high. Early season generation of P. rapae experienced little ant activity, and there was also substantial variation between sites and years. Within a patch of hosts at any one time, mortality due to ant predation was density-dependent. P. rapae larvae parasitized by the braconid parasite Apanteles glomeratus were more vulnerable to ant predation than were unparasitized larvae. Thus, the effects of ant predation and of parasitism are not cumulative. -from Author

dc:title: Kangaroos and climate: an analysis of distribution.
dc:creator: Caughley G.
dc:description: Macropus giganteus occupies areas only where rainfall either has little seasonal trend or where rainfall in summer exceeds winter rainfall. M. fuliginosus is found in areas of uniform or winter rainfall. Seasonality of rainfall has little influence on the distribution of M. rufus. Instead, its distribution reflects interaction between mean annual precipitation and mean annual temperature.-from Authors

dc:title: Efficient estimation of age-specific survival rates from ring recovery data of birds ringed as young, augmented by field information.
dc:creator: Lakhani K.
dc:description: Age-specific survival rates estimated only from a mixture of ringed young and adults are unsatisfactory being based on the assumption that all adults have the same recovery and survival rates in a given year. This assumption may be untrue for most species, and its use is liable to distort the estimates of the rate parameters. A scheme is proposed in which young and subadults are ringed in successive years. Estimation of the survival rates for older birds depends on constant recovery rate but no assumption is required for the young birds.-from Author

dc:title: The effect of prey density on foraging behaviour and success of adult and first-year grey herons ( Ardea cinerea).
dc:creator: Draulans D.
dc:description: Capture success of both adult and first-year grey herons was higher at high than at low prey densities with only few consistent changes from a prey density of 4500 fish ha-1 onwards, as predicted by the functional response models of Holling. Frequency of strikes and the energy intake per unit time showed similar increases, but strike frequency decreased at high fish densities. No indications of increased selectivity in prey sizes taken with increasing fish density were found. Intensity of fishing (number of orientations per unit time) and energy spend during hunting (number of steps per unit time) increased with prey density, but decreased sharply at high densities. Handling times did not constrain rate of capture at high prey densities. Rate of aggressive encounters increased significantly with number of steps taken per hunting bout, but aggression did not seem to interfere with rate of prey capture. Grey herons seemed to adjust their foraging efforts to the rate of success they were expecting to get. First-year grey herons were less successful at foraging than were adults when prey density was low, due to lower encouter rates with potential prey, but this difference decreased with increasing fish density. At very high densities both age classes performed similarly. Fishing success increases with prey density through increased encounter rates and the application of more intensive hunting strategies. Levelling-off in response at high prey densities is probably a consequence of birds becoming partly satiated within a short time. -from Author

dc:title: Effects of age and breeding experience on seasonal reproductive success in the song sparrow.
dc:creator: Nol E.
dc:description: For Melospiza melodia on Mandarte Island, Canada, pairs that raised many young in early broods raised fewer young in later broods. Older birds began breeding earlier than 1-yr old birds, and raised more young to independence, mainly because they had more successful attempts per season. Increases in breeding performance may be due to general improvements in survival skills with increasing age, or to increased reproductive effort, but are not related to breeding experience per se. Females breeding only as 1-yr olds raised fewer young per season than females that bred as older birds. Differential survival of female song sparrows with better breeding performance explains most of the apparent 'age effect' for birds of this sex.-from Authors

dc:title: The clonal ecology of Daphnia magna ( Crustacea: Cladocera). II. Thermal differentiation among seasonal clones.
dc:creator: Carvalho G.
dc:description: Results demonstrate marked thermal differentiation among D. magna clones from a single population. Major clonal frequency changes between seasons were directly related to differences in the thermal tolerance of specific genotypes.-from Author

dc:title: Causes of ecological success: the case of the ants. The sixth Tansley Lecture.
dc:creator: Wilson E.
dc:description: Can success be usefully defined in ants, and if so, which if any evolutionary strategies consistently confer it?-from Author

dc:title: Effects of altitude on the abundance and species richness of insect herbivores on bracken.
dc:creator: Lawton J.
dc:description: Only the delphacid bug Ditropis pteridis had a distribution that was clearly and consistently linked with altitude. As altitude increased, it occurred at fewer sites and became less abundant at occupied sites. Ditropis introduced onto Pteridium aquilinum above its normal altitudinal range reproduced successfully over the summer, but failed to overwinter, possibly because it could not synchronize its life-history with delayed emergence of bracken fronds in spring at high altitudes. The total number of species of bracken herbivores did not decline with altitude. As a resource for its insect herbivores, bracken is relatively similar at all altitudes. Declining host-plant species richness and reduced habitat area at high altitudes (rather than increasing environmental harshness) may be primarily responsible for the decline in insect species richness.-from Authors

dc:title: Limitation and regulation of population density in the nuthatch Sitta europaea (Aves) breeding in natural cavities.
dc:creator: Nilsson S.
dc:description: Survival of adults was 85% between 1 April and 1 November but only 54% between 1 November and 1 April (46% on an annual basis). Spring population size was positively related to winter temperatures and to winter food supply measured as the size of the preceding beech mast crop. Autumn numbers, but not winter survival rate, were higher when there was a big crop of beech mast. The main density-dependent factor, recruitment of young of the year to the autumn population, was positively related to the current beech mast supply and negatively to the density of adults. Number of young fledged had no effect on autumn recruitment. Territories with relatively high breeding success were more frequently occupied than low quality territories. An 8-fold increase in density of breeding pairs reduced the per capita breeding success by half. Part of this reduction was due to a lowered mean territory quality. Winter appears to be the limiting season, since most mortality of adults occurs then, but all density-dependent (regulatory) factors occur before winter. -from Author

dc:title: Poor acorn crop, dominance, and decline in numbers of acorn woodpeckers.
dc:creator: Hannon S.
dc:description: A poor acorn crop in 1983-84 altered the population dynamics and within-group social behaviour of the co-operatively breeding Melanerpes formicivorus at Hastings Reservation, California. Most territories were abandoned; on others, birds remained, but group size decreased over the winter. Winter loss was inversely related to the number of acorns per bird present in acorn storage trees the previous autumn. Most territories were recolonized in spring by at least one of the precious residents. Winter loss was higher than in other years with good acorn crops. Juveniles were lost from the population at the highest rate, followed by non-breeding helpers and then breeders. Aggressive interactions within groups that remained on their territories were intense and occurred when alternative food supplies were not available.-from Authors

dc:title: Factors determining the rate of parasitism by a parasitoid with a low fecundity, Chrysis shanghaiensis ( Hymenoptera: Chrysididae).
dc:creator: Yamada Y.
dc:description: The mechanism determining the rate of parasitism in the population interaction between the oriental moth Monema flavescens (Lepidoptera: Heterogeneidae), and its cocoon-attacking parasitoid, Chrysis shanghaiensis, was analysed. Both the host and the parasitoid had 1 and partly 2 generations a year. Parasitism by the chrysidid reached 60-70% in the 1st 2yr, but it did not exceed 50% in the last 2yr. The distribution of oviposition holes among host cocoons (one hole usually indicates that one egg was laid inside the cocoon) showed a high uniformity in the 1st generation, whereas in the 2nd generation the uniformity was decreased. The lower a host cocoon was placed on trees, the more likely it was to avoid parasitization. The rate of parasitism among cocoons placed near the ground, however, increased with the increase of the rate among the remaining cocoons. Also, the proportion of the cocoons near the ground in the whole cocoon population was usually low. Thus, this spatial refuge was not important as a determinant of the rate of parasitism. Early-spun cocoons of the 2nd generation were more likely to be parasitized. The proportion of 2nd generation cocoons vulnerable to parasitoid attack due to early spinning was 24.2-65.6%. The value of the 'area of discovery' varied greatly depending on the generations, and did not show a significant relationship with the parasitoid density, but the average number of oviposition holes made by each female parasitoid increased as the rate of female parasitoids to hosts increased.-from Author

dc:title: Food resource partitioning between sympatric populations of brackishwater sticklebacks.
dc:creator: Delbeek J.
dc:description: Adults of Apeltes quadracus, Gasterosteus aculeatus, G. wheatlandi and Pungitius pungitius appeared in the breeding areas near St Andrews, New Brunswick, in early May and were no longer present by the end of June. Juveniles appeared in late June, except for juvenile G. wheatlandi which did not appear until July because of their later breeding period. Juvenile Gasterosteus left the breeding areas by late August, while juvenile A. quadracus and P. pungitius remained. Food niche overlap was greatest between adult G. aculeatus and P. pungitius, while adult G. wheatlandi overlapped least with any species. Where A. quadracus was found in sympatry with the other species, overlap occurred with G. aculeatus and P. pungitius. The same relationships held for juveniles. In 4 of the 5 areas, niche breadth and overlap were greater in areas of high potential-prey density and lower in areas of low potential-prey density. In the 5th area, niche overlap was high at low potential-prey densities. No firm conclusion could be drawn about niche breadth relationships between species. Adults and juveniles exhibited similar microhabitat partitioning, although it was more pronounced in juveniles. A. quadracus fed predominantly from the benthos, while G. sheatlandi fed mainly in the water column. G. aculeatus and P. pungitius fed both the benthos and water column. P. pungitius usually foraged amongst algal mats.-from Authors

dc:title: Hatching asynchrony reduces parental investment in the jackdaw.
dc:creator: Gibbons D.
dc:description: Corvus monedula parents that reared asynchronous broods wasted less parental investment than parents that reared synchronous broods, because chicks of the former that starved did so at a younger age than chicks of the latter broods. -from Author

dc:title: Morphology, echolocation and resource partitioning in insectivorous bats.
dc:creator: Aldridge H.
dc:description: Two hypotheses are tested 1) wing morphology and echolocation-call 'design' can determine foraging site selection and foraging behaviour in bats; 2) echolocation-call 'design' should be compatible with wing morphology (because some combinations of morphology and echolocation call would be maladaptive). In support of the 1st hypothesis, significant correlations were established between wing morphology, echolocation call design, manoeuvrability and habitat use. In support of the 2nd hypothesis, significant correlations were established between those morphological parameters that improve manoeuvrability (low wingloading, low aspect ratio and high wingtip shape index) and echolocation calls that are resistant to acoustic clutter. There was an association between foraging habitat and diet: bats that fed in the same habitats tended to take the same types of prey, while species foraging in different habitats had significantly different diets. There was also a significant correlation between prey and predator size; large bats took insects over a range of sizes while small bats fed only on small prey.-Authors

dc:title: Responses in spatial organization and behaviour to manipulations of the food resource in the vole Clethrionomys rufocanus.
dc:creator: Ims R.
dc:description: Home ranges of reproductive females that had access to additional food became considerably smaller than those of females without additional food. Females that exploited the same supplemental food patch became more aggregated and had mutually more overlapping home ranges than other females. Home ranges of reproductive males overlapped extensively at high densities, but the overlap decreased radically as the number of reproductive males decreased. Females on the exclusive part of their home range showed site-specific dominance against foreign females. Females with supplemental food were more dominant towards strangers than females without, but showed amicable behaviour towards familiar females with whom they shared space and food. -from Author

dc:title: Persistence of stream invertebrate communities in relation to environmental variability.
dc:creator: Townsend C.
dc:description: Persistence of community structure was examined for benthic invertebrates at 27 stream sites in S England by comparing surveys in 1976 and 1984. Overall, persistence was greatest at low discharge, upstream sites with cool summer temperature regimes and low, stable pH.-from Authors

dc:title: Growth and feeding ecology of the Nile crocodile Crocodylus niloticus at Ngezi, Zimbabwe.
dc:creator: Hutton J.
dc:description: Juvenile growth was confined to the hot season and physical condition declined in the cool season. Large animals grew in in irregular spurts. Low cool-season growth was attributed to the physiological affects of temperature on feeding. Because growth was slow, females took c30 yr to reach sexual maturity. At a size of 600 mm SVL, the diet of juveniles changed from a predominance of insects to fish and birds and a concurrent reversal of several important allometric relationships of the head was believed to be an adaptation for the efficient capture of prey of an increasing size. A fundamental change of home range behaviour also occurred.-from Author

dc:title: Interactions between population density and maternal characteristics affecting fecundity and juvenile survival in red deer.
dc:creator: Clutton-Brock T.
dc:description: High population density increased differences in fecundity between young Cervus elaphus hinds and older animals on Rhum and between milk hinds and yeld hinds, but had no significant effect on relationships between maternal age or reproductive status and calf survival. Rising population density reduced the effects of matriline size on calf survival through the first winter and of the mother's dominance and matriline size on the survival of yearlings. At high population density, scramble competition between groups probably masks the effects of contest competition within them.-from Authors

dc:title: Intraspecific competition in sticklebacks ( Gasterosteidae: Pisces): does mother nature concur?
dc:creator: Whoriskey F.G.
dc:description: In Gasterosteus aculeatus and G. wheatlandi territory sizes were compressed at higher densities, the percentage of males able to build nests decreased at higher densities, but measured more closely correlated with reproductive success, ie the chances of getting at least one clutch of eggs and the number of eggs per male, were unrelated to density. The unpredictable effect of density upon egg predation suggests that the populations of sticklebacks at the site are not being regulated by intraspecific competition. Unpredictable environmental factors (temperature, dissolved oxygen cycling, water evaporation) mask any effects of intraspecific competition in the population regulation of the 2 species in the salt marsh.-from Authors

dc:title: Natal philopatry and breeding systems in voles ( Microtus spp.).
dc:creator: Boonstra R.
dc:description: In all 5 species, similar or larger proportions of males than females remained near the natal site as immature animals and both sexes moved similar distances from the natal site if they remained immature. In the mainland species of voles - M. californicus, M. ochrogaster, M. pennsylvanicus, M. townsendii - about twice as many females as males matured near their natal site regardless of whether the mating system was monogamous or polygynous, suggesting that females in both monogamous and polygynous species primarily compete for resources, and males compete for access to females. In the island species, M. breweri, and in enclosed populations (some with and some without an opportunity to disperse) of M. ochrogaster, M. pennsylvanicus and M. townsendii, similar proportions of males and females remained near the natal site as mature animals. Thus preventing or reducing dispersal eliminated the bias towards female philopatry. Nevertheless, in all of these species, mature males still moved about twice as far from the natal sites as females. Males in polygynous species from control populations, if they did mature within the population, tended to move farther from the natal site than females; males in the one monogamous species showed no such difference. Thus, though male-male competition may be a primary cause of male dispersal, inbreeding avoidance may be a secondary cause. The basic social organization in females (all species) is probably based on female kin cluster. -from Authors

dc:title: Breeding seasons on North Scandinavian starlings ( Sturnus vulgaris): constrained by food or time?
dc:creator: Lundberg P.
dc:description: Starlings of Andoya, N Norway, regularly reared 2 broods each year and were sedentary, whereas starlings in Umea, N Sweden, reared a single brood and were migratory. The potential prey fauna extracted from soil core samples revealed a parallel seasonal variation at both locations, both with respect to prey abundance and biomass. Moreover, the spatial distribution of potential prey did not show any consistent variation over time at either location. Starlings in Umea terminated their breeding season when the food supply began to decrease, but starlings at Andoya reared an additional brood, albeit smaller than the first one. Food supply alone cannot account for differences in the breeding patterns. The inter-relation with other annual processes, such as moult and migration, might increase the costs of an additional brood, ultimately terminating the breeding season.-from Author

dc:title: Age-related effects in oystercatchers, Haematopus ostralegus, feeding on mussels, Mytilus edulis. III. The effect of interference on overall intake rate.
dc:creator: Goss-Custard J.
dc:description: Number of juvenile oystercatchers using the mussel bed increased from August to October, but decreased by over half from October to November as birds moved during low tide to other habitats, including nearby grass fields. Thereafter, there were more juveniles on the mussel bed on cold days when the earthworms in the fields were more difficult to catch. Intake rate of both juveniles and adults feeding on mussels in winter decreased as bird density increased. In juveniles, the decrease began at lower densities of birds. The density of foraging birds in the parts of the mussel bed where juveniles fed was highest during the first and last fifths of the highly variable exposure period. Bird density was highest on neap tides and lowest on spring tides at all stages of the tidal cycle. The potential maximum rate at which a bird could feed was assumed to be set by its intake rate in the absence of competitors. In winter, bird density was high enough on neap tides for interference to depress the average intake rate of juveniles through the tidal cycle to 59% of their potential maximum. The corresponding values for mid and spring tides were 74% and 82%, respectively. Intake rate of adults was depressed on neap tides to 64% of their potential maximum, but because adults were less prone to interference than juveniles, their intake rate was rather less affected on mid tides (86%) and spring tides (91%). Interference was probably suffiently important in young oystercatchers in particular to make their mortality rate dependent on population size. -from Authors
